clinical_study.official_title: The Neonatal Microbiome Study: Validity of Biologic Sample Collection Methods

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York at Buffalo

clinical_study.source: State University of New York at Buffalo

brief_summary.textblock: This is a validation study to compare proposed field collection methods with a gold standard collection technique for microbiome analysis of stool and breast milk samples.

detailed_description.textblock: In order to conduct a future study of the gut microbiome in a population living in a rural, low income setting, this validation study will be conducted to verify the validity of our proposed field collection methods for stool and breast milk samples. We will compare the microbial diversity and abundance in the biologic samples using various proposed field collection methods to an immediately frozen sample. The proposed field collection methods are feasible for use in a community-based study in a low income setting with limited access to cold storage.

primary_outcome.measure: Difference in intestinal microbiome between gold standard and proposed field protocol
primary_outcome.description: Comparison of microbiome from snap-frozen sample (gold standard) to proposed field collection methods to determine which field method best correlates with the snap-frozen sample.

primary_outcome.measure: Difference in breast milk microbiome between gold standard and proposed field protocol
primary_outcome.description: Comparison of microbiome from snap-frozen sample to proposed field collection methods to determine which field method best correlates with the snap-frozen sample.

biospec_descr.textblock: Stool and breast milk samples will be collected. Bacterial DNA will be isolated and stored. Human DNA will not be retained in these samples.

study_pop.textblock: A convenience sample of men/women willing to provide a stool sample and/or breast milk sample.
